TEXT.TEXTVALUE: Arrange the reagents and materials required for the experiment on the lab table.Click on each apparatus/reagents to know its name or click on the “Continue” to start the experiment.
The bottle containing copper sulphate is opened and some amount of the copper sulphate powder is taken from it.
The weigh balance is TARED and the powder is then transferred to the blotting paper kept on the weigh balance and 0.2g of the copper sulphate is weighed.
The weighed powder is then transferred to a beaker and the bottle containing distilled water is opened.
Measure out 20ml of distilled water using a measuring cylinder.
The measured distilled water is then added to the beaker containing the copper sulphate solution.
And stir the contents using a glass rod. Label it as “Solution A”.
Add 0.4 gm of sodium potassium tartarate into a beaker.
Using measuring cylinder, 20 ml of distilled water is measured.
Using measuring cylinder, 20 ml of distilled water is measured.
The distilled water is then transferred to the beaker containing sodium potassium tartarate .
Stir the contents using a glass rod. Label it as “Solution B”.
Add 3.6g of sodium carbonate into a beaker.
The standard flask containing 0.1N NaOH is opened .
Using a measuring cylinder, measure out 180ml of 0.1N NaOH.
The measured 0.1N NaOH is transferred to the beaker containing sodium carbonate.
Stir the contents using a glass rod. Label it as “Solution C”.
A micropipette is taken and adjust the volume to 1000microlitre.
A new micropipette tip is then inserted .
Using the micropipette, pipette out 1ml of Solution A from the beaker.
Transfer the measured solution into a new beaker.
The micropipette tip is then discarded.
Again the micropipette volume is adjusted to 1000microlitre.
A new micropipette tip is then inserted .
Using the micropipette, pipette out 1ml of Solution B from the beaker.
Transfer the measured solution into beaker containing Solution A.
A glass pipette is fixed into the pipette pump.
Using the pipette, pipette out 9ml of the solution C from the beaker.
Transfer the measured solution into the beaker containing Solution A and Solution B.
A glass rod is taken from the lab bench.
The contents in the beaker is stirred thoroughly using the glass rod.
The lid of the stoppered conical flask is opened and the solution mixture from the beaker is now transferred to the conical flask.
Label the conical flask as “Alkaline Copper Reagent”.
The test tubes are labelled and arranged in the test tube rack.
A micropipette is taken and the volume is adjusted to 200microlitre.
A new micropipette tip is then inserted into the pipette.
The lid of the standard flask containing Standard Protein solution is removed and pipette out 200 microlitre of the solution from the standard flask.
Transfer the pipetted solution into the test tube labelled “0.2”.
The micropipette volume is then adjusted to 400 microlitre.
The lid of the standard flask containing ‘Standard Protein solution’ is removed and pipette out 400 microlitre of the solution from the standard flask.

Transfer the pipetted solution into the test tube labelled “0.4”. Similarly pipette out 600 microlitre,800 microlitre,1000 microlitre of the standard protein solution to the respective labelled test tubes.Pipette out 500 microlitre of the unknown solution to the test tube labelled “Unknown”.
Now all the test tube, except “Blank “ is filled with protein solution.
A micropipette is taken and volume is adjusted to 1000 microlitre.
1000 microlitre of distilled water is then pipetted out from the beaker.
Transfer the pipetted water into the test tube labelled “Blank”.
The micropipette volume is then adjusted to 800 microlitre .
800 microlitre of distilled water is pipetted out from the beaker.

Transfer the pipetted water into the test tube labelled “0.2”. Similarly pipette out 600 microlitre , 400 microlitre , 200 microlitre and 500 microlitre of distilled water to the respective labelled test tubes to make up the solution in all the test tubes to 1ml.
A glass pipette is fixed into the pipette pump.
The lid of the Alkaline Copper Reagent bottle is opened and using the glass pipette, pipette out 5ml of the solution from the bottle.
Transfer the pipetted Alkaline Copper reagent to the test tube labelled “Blank”.
Similarly transfer 5ml of Alkaline copper reagent to all the test tubes.
Note the change in colour observed in each test tube.
The test tube labelled Blank is taken for mixing the contents.
The test tube is then kept on the slot of the vortex mixer for vortexing.
Similarly keep all the test tubes in the vortex mixer for mixing the contents in the test tube.
All the test tubes were then kept for incubation at room temperature for 10 minutes.
A micropipette is taken and volume is adjusted to 600 microlitre .
A new micropipette tip is then inserted into the pipette.
The lid of the bottle containing Folin’s Ciocalteau reagent is then opened and using the pipette, pipette out 600 microlitre of the reagent from the bottle.
600 microlitre of folin’s reagent is added to each test tube.
The test tube containing “Blank” is taken for vortexing.
Similarly vortex all the test tubes in the vortex mixer.
The test tubes were then kept for incubation at room temperature for 20 minutes.
The test tube containing “Blank” is taken.
Transfer the solution from the test tube to a cuvette till the specified mark .
The cuvette is then placed into the slot of the colorimeter. TARE the colorimeter to zero.
notext
Then the test tube labelled “0.2” is taken.
Transfer the solution from the test tube to a cuvette till the specified mark.
The cuvette is kept in the colorimeter and record the absorbance.
notext
A graph is plotted with Amount of protein in mg Vs OD at 650nm. We get a straight line which is the Protein standard curve. Now plot the OD values of the unknown and extrapolate it to the X-axis.
Calculate the amount of protein present in the unknown sample using the formula.
